sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, there was Light-body, Laurie, Latie, Cheisly quoque Brounie, Bowique Hi enim sunt Tuscanii gloria summa soli: besides our hospes, what d'you call him, Architabernarius, or Arch-taverner, who is one of the commissioners for administration of— drink— to the people of Tuscania.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Don't you enquire for Signior Becabunga, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, the very same, where is he? ubinam est?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: You will find him at the Verona●tavern, hard by, with some of his comrades.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Say you so, I will go find him then, profecto I think I could scarce abstaine from vapulating him for this his contumacy.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Now Leonardo, 'tis time we were stirring, if we do not, this match will go on.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Nay, I'l do any thing for thee, e're thou lose her, Cassio,

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Come then; I have almost gull'd Pantaloni into a belief, that Becabunga wrongs him, for which he swears he will be revenged: now, if you can do the same with the other, our design may succeed yet.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Well, go you about your business then, fear not me.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Now, wit and art assist us both, I'l search my gamester and accomplish the trick.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: MAdam, I will conduct you to him once again, but you must be very secret, for I hazard my life and reputation, if my Lord Borasco have intelligence of this, for he gave me strict command this morning, that I should admit none to him but his confessor.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: I shall be very secret, I warrand you.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: Come then, soft Madam, soft.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For heavens sake good my Lord,
sp.stage: Exeunt, she enters again with Marciano.
sp.l: Vpon my knees I beg it—

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: This is impossible; I cannot do it;
Prove not a sweet Remora any more,
I'me now resolv'd: look to thy self, fair gemme.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Cannot the tears of innocence prevaile.
Where is your courage now? what? are you cool?
Is all that noble blood, that formerly
Run in your veines exhausted? must a woman
Become your Trumpeter, and stirr your spirits
Since 'tis but death at all hands—

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Prethee hold,
I would most willingly (as what man will doubt)
Procure my liberty by what ever meanes
But— O here lyes my fear, thou, thou bright love,
May come to suffer by it—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ah my Lord.
Consider pray' that I have liberty
To go abroad at pleasure: I have gain'd
The Lord Borasco's favour: he will grant me
That which some dare not ask, nay must not think on.
I'le follow you without the least suspition.
Consider that— Strenuo hath promised
To entertaine the Jaylor in his cups,
While you be safely escap'd.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I'le hazard then:
Bright angel of my fancy, see you follow
Immediatly, for e're you should endure
The rebells censure, I would rather forfait
A thousand lives.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Doubt not of that, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Then once for all— O my good stars direct me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Farewell, my Lord, goodnesse protect you still

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Farewell pure quintessence of my affection
Farewell, pray heavens grant us a joyfull meeting.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now, now at length, I hope he shall escape;
O supreme powers, assist him now, or never,
And ease my soul of its long burning fever.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: SIr, (as your friend, I speak it) Leonardo and he have joyn'd their wits together to affront you; and you will not beleeve what impression their false suggestions of you have taken upon the Lady Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I! So I thought, when she told me last day that she would consult forsooth: A pox take all your consulting tricks, say I, for I never knew any good come of womens consultations yet.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Right Sir, you might easily smell Leonardo's plot in that same word, for he intends that Becabunga shall have Marionetta, and he himself Chrysolina: for which Becabunga does sollicite your Mistris all this while: if you look not to your self quickly you are undone, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I, so I guessed alwayes, for, d'you see, some women, are the most humourous little creatures, a man shall not know when he is in their favour, and when not: but as for Becabunga— I'le say no more at this time: but I vow I'le cudgell him to death so soon as I can see him.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: And please but command me, you shall not want my assistance, I'le assure you.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p:
Now Sir, I shall not need your help to beat such a puppet
as he is: what would you think to write a challenge to him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: So you know, I advis'd you at first, when I sent for you to the Taberna del. Reina, while you beleeved that Becabunga had sent for you.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Hang him, I will hear no more of him: I will write a challenge to him presently.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: And if you'll please to take my advice in penning on't, I will so terrifie him.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, for I would have it such language as might make him hang himself for fear: and for Leonardo, after I have discussed Becabunga then have at him.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: If you please to employ me to carry it to him?

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Yes Sir, you shall go along with me, and help me to write it, for the truth is I am not much us'd with such challenges, and my mother bid me allwayes have a care of quarrelling, but an she were burn'd I'le fight with that rascall, who has affronted me so.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: A most generous resolution.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Come with me Sir.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Now, Leonardo, play thy game, or never.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Marciano solus, disguis'd as having escap'd

sp.l: — THanks to my stars! as yet unknown
I have cheat all the sentinells; and now
I suck free aire again:— you powers above
Direct my suddain course: and save my love.
Within.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.l: Ho, wher's the pisse-pot there.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Sirrah drawer, 'tother quart of sack, you raggamuffin you.

div.stage: Courtain drawn appear Str. and the Jaylor, drinking.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p:
You shall do me reason Signior Strenuo:— 'tis my noble
Generals health, Signior Strenuo— Ho, where's the piss-pot there?— you shall drink it, Signior—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come then, we'll drink his good health, although he has but two dayes to live.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: No matter for that, I love to be courteous to the last breath, Signior; come, give me the cup: drinks. Sack, good Sack, Signior drinks again.— O brave Sack; come, lets have a catch, Signior.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Come then— Here's a health to the pretty little thing,
With the bony, bony radiant eyes,
And the bony, bony, plump, round thighs;
Let us sing— let us sing—

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: Let us sing, let us sing— O brave Strenuo, here's a cup to thee for thy catch. drinks.

div.stage: Enter a Servant, beckens to Str. Str. approaches to him.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He is escap'd.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: 'Tis good, no more, silence I command you.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He waits for you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Plague on you, no more I say.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lord is escap'd I say.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pox take you, hold your peace, or you'l spoil all I say.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: Come young-man, how does my noble General? you are his servant, I know— here's to him, a brimmer of Sack.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Drink and be gone, you cocks-comb you—

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: You shall pledge me neighbour.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I shall, Sir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: My Lord has ordained me to present his love and respects to all friends at my return to Siena— get you gone whoreson, get you gone, or you'l spoil all.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: Well, he's a noble Gentleman, Signior, although I dare not say it: but, no more of him, this cup is yours, Signior, we'll have t'other flaggon of Sack e're we part; for I love to be merry as well as courteous, especially amongst strangers, Signior— Ho, drawer, Sirrah, Loggar-head, the piss-pot, Bastard, shall a man spoil his breeches, you son of a whore you.

div.stage: Enter Strenuo quietly with the Servant.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You puppet you, could not you hold your peace when I bid you— come, where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: At the Colonna in the Strada del Popolo, there he lurks quietly while you come to him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let the rogue the Jaysor slip then, and we'll bid adieu to Florence; come, come quickly.

div.head: Scaena Quinta.

sp.l: — SO, now he's gone: O! how my heart does leap,
My pulse begins to move, since now I know
He's past the rebels reach, before this time.
All's well: this day, by order of the Senate,
Am I to be enlarg'd: had Marciano,
Whose understanding soul, div'd in the deepest
Gulfs of suspition, even but conjectur'd,
How e're they could accuse me for his flight.
Had rather died, e're he had condescended
To any such attempt— but now he's safe,
I'l follow close my self: So hope assist me.

div.stage: A noise within of many voices, crying confusedly, Souldiers searching for Marciano. Enter Jaylor, weeping and railing.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: A pox on all your Stennois tricks, say I, plague on that villain Strenuo: my noble General's gone, fled, gone: what shall I do? How the devil came I to be gull'd by that name Strenuo! The last night while he and I were deep in our cups, my noble General breaks the prison and escapes. O! plague on his crazy cocks-comb, I could have trusted him assoon as any in Florence, and yet he hath played me such a trick as may bring me to a ropes end yet—
Harke— my Lord Borasco searching me, I shall be hang'd without doom or sentence—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Where is this villain?

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.l: Here am I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You ugly scarabe, what do you deserve?
Sirrah, you shall be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.l: Alas! my Lord,
I was deceived, grossly cheated, gull'd,
Fox'd and what not, by Signior Strenuo;
A plague on him, may I say—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Peace, you wretch,
My Lord Barbaro will cause punish you
For your neglect, For he had ne're escap'd
Had he not bryb'd you—

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.l: I never see his coyn.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Good gods! this day was he to be beheaded,
Now none knows where he is— this Siennois Lady
Will be examin'd: for she seem'd to carry
A great respect to him: and (this I know)
The Senate will suspect her accessory,
No doubt: So she shall be condemn'd to die:
But I'l prevent their severe resolutions
By all means possible— Come, you Scoundrel, come
You may be hang'd yet, Sirrah, e're all be done.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.l: O! no more of that word hanging, my neck itches already.

div.head: Scaena Sexta.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: CAn you desire any more? look you, Sir, a direct challenge.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I know not what belongs to your challenges; but I am sure, as you say, he has affronted me.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Sir, the very words of this challenge would encourage one; considering especially, that he is the basest coward that ever breath'd for all this.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Think you so?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Sir, I warrand you he dare never appear in field against you: he is but a bragging fellow.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Nay, if I thought he would not appear, I might say something.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Trust me, Sir, he dares not.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I, but d'you hear, Sir, if we can be handsomly reconciled, what needs fighting?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Fy, Sir, you cannot honourably refuse, when he has writ a challenge to you.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Not, Sir, why cannot I write another to him, and cal him a coward, a rascal, a slave, a villain, and what not, and still preserve my honour, as you call it?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Alas! good Sir, there's no time now to talk, now you must fight, and I will assist you.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I, if you will hold him to me while I beat him, there may be something on't too.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Doubt not, Sir; but, as I told you, he dares not appear, you have no more to do, but come arm'd to the fields, and if you find him not, brandish your Rapier in the air thrice, proclaim him a coward, and so return.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: With my honour, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, with your honour entire.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Well, I see I must fight; but if he doth not appear now, I shall be in a brave condition: for, then I will swear, rant and domineer, by my word of honour, as my fathers foot-groom does. But will he not come, think you?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: My life for't, he dares not appear; courage, we will out-dare both him and Cassio.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Well, but when all's done, Sir, betwixt you and me, were I at home in the Country again, all your honour, and honour above honour, should not cause me fight: for, Pantaloni has learn'd to fence, Sir, and I know not what belongs to fencing, not I.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Tush, fear not him, I tell you, he dares not appear, and if he does, I'l fight him my self.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Will you do so, Sir, and I will be your tres humble serviteur Monsieur: for, d'you see, Sir, I am to be married shortly, now if I should chance to be kill'd, (as who knowes but I may) you know then, Sir, I cannot be marryed; why? because I shall be dead, that's a good reason, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Plague on him for a coward, how he talks; I shall have more ado to allure him to this duel, then a crack'd Courtier has to perswade an Usurer to become surety for him.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: And then you know, Sir, Pantaloni is to marry the one Sister, and I the other: now it is not fit that we should fight together, who are to be brethren shortly, for I know not what.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p:
Why, Sir, you must resolve to fight: go along with me
to the field: and if he offer to thrust at you, I'le step in betwixt, and save you both.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Will you be as good as your word, Sir? Leon. I will indeed.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Then have at him— But harke you, Sir, you must have a speciall care he touch not my face, for so he may put but my eye (God blesse us) and then where is your honour forsooth?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: He shall not touch you Sir, come, delay is dangerous.

div.stage: At the other end Enter Cass. Pant. traverse &c.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You may stand by, and see fair play, Sir, I shall beat him to some purpose: Cass. As you think fit, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Come on then— O Becabunga! thou knowes not how nigh thy fatall hour approaches— for I am sure he dares not appear.

div.head: Scaena Septima.
div.stage: Enter Arabella sola in Prison, more closely confin'd, then formerly upon the report that she was to be beheaded.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O gods! is this the height of all your wrath:
May I expect a requiem in this stroak?
Yes sure— then graciously be pleas'd to hear
My ardent votes:— O may my blood appease
Your incens'd mindes: restore my lawfull Prince:
Let Marciano live: Let nothing hurt him:
O hear him, hear him, if there be a faith
Able to reach your mercy, let him have it.
I plead none for my self:— O love assist me,
Courage, beyond the ordinar of my sex,
Support my spirits in this agony:
Death's but the thaw of all our vanity.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Nay now my soul dissolve: 'tis but a trouble
To keep thy quarter in this perplexed body.
O unkind Senate! eyes have not seen a fairer
Modell of beauty— Sure, no hatchet dares
Be horse-leech to her veines: or if it does,
All iron shall be quite accurs'd hereafter.
— No, ther's an angell keeps that paradice
A fiery angell guards her: Vertue, vertue,
Ever, and endlesse vertue! O rare beauty!
The neerest to her maker, and the purest,
That ever dull flesh shew'd us: such another
Could make attonement for half her sex.
— See how she weeps—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: — So, now my torturer comes—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Now all good angells blesse thee, fairest, truest
Heart-ravishing beauty: cruell, yet lovely tyrant.
Why still in sorrow? shall I never have
One gracious smile— A las, how willingly
To save thy precious life would I submitt
My neck to cruelty— by this hand, I would—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Since it is ordain'd, Sir, I'le not endeavour
To prove a male-content. Sir, I have done
What I intended; shee's a cowardly Girle,
Who cann't endure one stroke for him, whose safety
Is so dear to his prince and country, vex not
Your self for my misfortunes: nothing can
Affright my resolutions—

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Strange love! not to be parallel'd?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Pish— I contemn the fury of your base,
Malicious senate: reason does disdain
To dwell with such, whose souls are stiffled with rage,
They sentence, whom they will, no matter why,
Since innocent, or guilty, we must dye.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Madam, you shall not dye I will sollicit
The Senate for you: if I cannot prevaile
As I expect, before it come to th'worst
I'le set you free, although their fury reach
In going off. My person for it— who does enterprise
To serve his fancy, must all feares despise.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ah vain fomenter of vain, fruitlesse hopes,
Thy windmill-thoughts will break their axel-tree:
Go foolish enterpriser: hope no favour
From one, who e're she suffered thy embraces,
Would rather undergo a thousand tortures.
— No, if e're woman was, or may be found,
That for fair fame, unspotted memory,
For vertues sake, and only for it's sake
Dares challenge room in history: O love
Let me be only Martyr in the case.
O Marciano, were it not thy safety
That did support my soul, I should prevent
The executioner: but since thou art
Free from the rav'nous clutches of the rebells,
Poor Arabella from that spark alone
Derives her present courage—
— Then blessed hour approach, I'le boldly show
That for his life, I can endure one blow.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: THis is the place, this is the hour appointed.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but, you see, he has not appear'd, may not I put up my rapier now, and go home again with my honour, may I not?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Not Sir: you must have a little patience.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Ho, Ho, that's very true, I must proclaime Leonardo and him both cowards— Oyes— Oyes—
But (a pox) I hear them comming hither. Come, Signior Cassio, wee have tarried too long, we will now return.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: No, no, stay a little yet.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I see this fellow has a mind I should be kill'd: would I had that unlucky challenge in my pocket again.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: 'Slid, here they come; to your posture, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: O! look you there's Pantaloni, Sir, and Cassio too, you said he durst not appear.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay faith, now I see 'tis no more jesting, there they come both with their Rapiers drawn.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Courage, Signior.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: What shall I do now, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Fight, what else?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: We'll fight all four at once.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Yes, yes, by all means:

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Have at thee then, villain, Leonardo.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: At you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Come, to't Becabunga.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Not I, Sir; as I am honest I will fight none at this time: for I have some business to do in the City, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: What, you sneaking gull, will you not fight for your Mistris, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: No, Sir, I will fight for no Mistris at this time; I must go about business of more importance, Sir— aside. O! if he had not appear'd now.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Not for the Lady Marionetta, Sir?

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: No, Sir, I will renounce all the right I have to her, before I fight, at this time at least.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I like that well.

sp.speaker: Cass,
sp.p: 'Slid, shall we come to the fields with you, and return thus affronted? fight it out bravely, or by this hand I'l run you both thorough.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay, it shall not be so, Sir, you see we cannot fight at this time: for, the truth is, (now when I remember) I have an appointment too, within less then a minute of an hour hence, with some Ladies of my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: That's all one to us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I see I must do it, there is no way else to escape— aside. Gentlemen, I know what will please you: because we have brought you into the fields, that you may not be angry, as Becabunga sayes, I will renounce all the right I can have or claim in the Lady Chrysolina.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Good—

sp.speaker: Pant,
sp.p: For, d'you see, Sir, I care no more for her, then a Roarer does for his old Punk.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I protest to you, Sir, I think they are fools that fight for women, let them fight for themselves a Gods name, it is sufficient we love them.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Admirably good!

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: So I say too Sir, and if you have wrong'd me, I here freely forgive you.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Sir, that's not enough, you shall both seal this paper, that we may testifie to other Gentlemen, how we were ready to fight.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: What paper, Sir?

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: No matter for that, Sir, you shall both seal it, or by these hilts—

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay hold, good Sir, I shall seal it— what terrible oaths these fellowes use.

sp.speaker: Cass
sp.p: Come, you must seal too.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Now get you gone both of you for a brace of infamous puppets, cowardly cocks-combs, you arrogant, empty-skull'd wittals, not worthy of the least favourable smile from any Lady: you have resign'd your interests in two honourable Ladies, and therefore deserve no less then to be kick'd— thus to be kick'd—

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: What d'you mean, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Thus to kick you, you brace of bastardly Baboons—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: And so we leave you as we found you, a pair of impudent filchers of reputation, not worthy the name of Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Farewell my Cob-webs—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Farewell good Spanniels, farewell—

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Marry pox take you both, what notorious rascals are they.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Come, come, we must be friends again; let them go hang themselves if they please.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: If I had them in another place—

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: But harke you, what if they show the Ladies that we have renounc'd our interest in them? what will you say then? think you that ever the Lady Chrysolina will look upon you again.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I should have made them both black and blew.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Will you let's go and prevent them, I say.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: By all means— this trick shall do Leonardo no good, what a fool was I to believe Cassio?

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: So I say alwayes: but come, quick— he that speaks first is alwayes best heard.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I'l to them yet, for all this, he has not beat me out as I thinks.

div.head: Scaena Nona.
div.stage: Enter Marciano solus, having got intelligence that Arabella was to die.

sp.l: — HEart! art thou thunder-proof? can nothing break 〈◊〉
Shall Arabella die, and tho ●still live?
— Burst stubborn peece of flesh— O! heavens forbid,
Those eyes may live to see the world without her.
— The Senate hath condemn'd her— O! base wre●●
Unhumane Tyrants; Monsters of this age;
O! barbarous villany; what bloody thoughts?
It is not because she was accessory
To my escape: No sure, but 'cause I love her,
That she must die; as if those hell-hounds mean'd
To strike the Stars, and all good things above,
Regardless of her deity: no devil
Could be more cruel— But, hold, Marciano,
Thou ar't the executioner: thou alone.
Say, wretched man, was thou affraid to die?
Could fear prevail so far? Alas! thy fame
Has lost it's right wing by thy too rash flight,
Leaving so rare an hostage in thy place.
Yet, who had said, or who had ever thought,
A thing so closely carryed could have ever
Thus come to light. She was to be enlarg'd
That very day: for so she did assure me,
Else had my wearied soul resign'd it's casket,
And I, by this time, sleep'd with blessed shades
Of my Ancestors, maugre all her tears.
— But what, I dream, I must do something more
Then only mourn for her: if art assist,
●l study to preserve her; either return,
Submit my self to mercy of the Rebels,
●f otherwayes those goblins cann't be conjur'd,
Or else by open force, or private means.
What e're be th'event, I'l procure her freedom:
May be the gods are more propitious
Then I imagine. Come— it is resolv'd
in going off. She shall not die— fools are amaz'd at fate,
Griefs but conceal'd are never desperate.
NAy hold, my spleen; do not burst yet—
How this same Lady hath abus'd my favour,
Escap'd, no man knows how; gone, God knows whether.
If I fly not, I shall supply her place,
That is resolv'd I know— Fortune, you shall not
Play upon me; although you now begin
To frown upon most of our Senators:
For, since the brave Lord Barbaro is dead,
All such as were his creatures are discarded;
Amongst whom, I am one— a plague on all
Your base seditious cocks-combs: your proceedings
Will strengthen Cleons interest. Hell-hounds, Tygars,
Adieu base Elves: I'l post to Venice straight,
And there evite the ruine of your State.

div.head: Scaena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Pantaloni, Becabunga, with Chrysolina, Marionetta.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: TUsh, these are all but stories, Madam, I was but jesti● with them when I did it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sir, I will hear no excuse.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I vow 'tis true, Madam

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay, but harke you, Madam Chrysolina, if you come to that with it, I can make you love me yet, whether you will or no.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Will you, Sir? Chrys. Pray, how do you that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Why, thus I instruct it, Madam; I can show you several Letters under your own hand and seal, day and date, &c. that you are my humble servant, which you dare not for your ears deny, dare you? Chrys. You had best be silent.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay more, I know you love me yet, because the last time I was with you, you gave me a knot of Ribbons, which my mother keeps well lock'd up in her Cabinet yet, as a love-token: and moreover, when I said I will come and see you again to morrow, you said, sayes you, you shall be welcom.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: This will not do it, Sir, you have renounced us, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: Nay hold, Madam, we were but in jest.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And then they forced us to do it.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I, and if we had not done it, they swore (God blesse us) that they would kill us.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And then, you know, it was better to seal a peece of paper then to be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: What strong arguments they use.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Sister, we must shake e'm off now or never.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: And then, Madam, if we had been kill'd—

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Yes, if we had been kill'd, it had been small advantage for you.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: aside. I, and then, Madam— and then, I say, Oh! if Manduco were here to plead for me now.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay, if you will not hear us, take your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: No more, Sir, get you gone, henceforth I disclaim you.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And I you too, d'you see; I care no more for you, Miris, then you do for me: I am as good a Gentleman as your self; and if you were not a woman I would tell you more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I knew it would alwayes come to this at length, I vow; think you Gentle women do nothing but entertain us with vain hopes for a while, and then cast us off.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Mistris, shall I tell you, there are more Ladies in Florence ●he● you that will be blyth of me yet; and so long as I have money in store, I am sure to have Mistresses in store.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: Are you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I that I am; but I will complain to your Uncle, to the Lady Saromanca, and to all your kindred, that you have cheat me, for all your fair promises.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: You are a prating fool.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I am no more prating then your self, Mistris; but if there be justice to be had of you, I'l have it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Come, let us leave them, Sister, else they'll both fall a weeping.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: For whom, for you, Mistris? I'l let you know we are no such children.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: No, but, I protest, I cannot but weep though.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: Mar. Farewell, farewell, march to your travels my Gamesters, farewell.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Peugh— Farewell; I believe you are the greatest fool of the two, Madam Chrysolina, call they you.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I protest, Pantaloni, I am very sorry for the loss of this bony Lady though. O! how my father will chide me now: for he had given Manduco orders to provide my Wedding-cloaths, and now all's blown up.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Come, come, we know the worst on't: let them go, we will never want great matches yet; let us think now to be revenged on them villains, Cassio and Leonardo: the first time I meet any of them, I will cut the tongue out of their heads that they shall never talk more.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I, so will I too: but we must have Manduco with us then, for he will make them stand in awe of him.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Marciano solus, as at Pisa.

sp.l: THat she's escap'd, that, I know certainly,
So letters from Siena have inform'd me.
But by what means, or where she is, I know not.
Never remembers him, who, if he should
Forget her but one hour, would think he had
Offended highly, yet she's silent still.
If I receive no letters from her, shortly,
I'le become jealous of her, sure; that she,
Who was all love, is now so quickly cold
In her affections.— But what! I blaspheme
The vertuous Arabella, she's all vertue,
And cannot prove unconstant—
Now let me meditate on what my Prince
Hath order'd me to do: He's still the same,
And bears a mind, that floats above the waves
Of all adversities, as who should say,
Fortune, even do thy worst. His Counsellours,
Like to wise Marriners, affray'd to stretch
The top sayles of their courage in this tempest,
Least both they, and their Prince should suffer shipwrack.
Only was I commanded some years since
Upon an expedition to Siena,
Encourag'd by th'affectionate expressions,
And actions of the valiant Cassanaeo,
And others of our loyal country-men.
But fortune crush'd our enterprises, so
I did return to Savoy, where my Prince
Did then reside: and now, I am commanded
To second here an enterprise at Pisa,
Which whether it succeed or not; my duty
Is yet at least to prosecute it—
How's this— a post-horn: good—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: All's well, my Lord, now do our joyes begin.
To flourish after such a tedious winter.
The Duk's restor'd, and now intends at Florence.
Here, here's a letter for it, from himself.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Restor'd!— Nay hold my heart— I'l read this letter.
— True, True:— O fortune how I hugge thee now.
And thou my good friend Strenuo—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: Brave dayes, my Lord; the Court does fill apace,
The Ladies croud in throngs: the glory of
Her sex, your darling, the fair Arabella,
Since clouds of melancholly are overblown,
Does now appear in loves full horizon.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O how propitious! lend me moderation,
Reins to my joy, as well as to my sorrow,
Else, I shall quickly burst to death: this bless'd,
And unexpected Tarantula: of news
So ticles all my senses:— joyfull tidings!
My Prince restor'd! my dearest Arabella
At Court I now my felicity lacks nothing
But sight to be compleat: that my eyes may
Perswade my yet almost incredulous soul,
To what my fancy never durst have prompted
— To horse— To horse, I'le post to Florence quickly.

div.head: Scaena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Pantaloni, Becabunga, and Manduco with swords by their sides.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O Tempora! O mores! O the effraenate, licentious perversity of untamed adolescency! what a villanous, scelerate attempt to entice two young Gentlemen to a Duel: who besides, that they are both innocent Boyes, why, their very Uncles and other friends, are employed in serious negotiations of the Senate. Prob Deum, atque hominum fidem! Is all my industry in sollicitation, my immense study and lucrubrations for framing familiar epistles, my oratory in private commendations and exhortations for both these Gentlemen come to nought!— Proh facinus ingens!

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Peace, Mr. Manduco: you must not only teach us how to beat, but likewise assist us in beating these dissolute fellows; for I have sworn, Sir, and that is enough—

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: I, so I say too, for, you know we wear our swords here for no other end; look you, are not my hilts very handsome, O now, I will swear, By these hilts, as well as Leonardo himself.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And for that effect, I have got my sword too: I am lenis in puniendo: but when I am provoked, invenient me Leonem, they shall find me a very Lyon: my schollars at Santo Burgo, where I was sometimes ludimagister, can yet testifie that: and for my severity in castigando— Probatum est.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Although Leonardo has got my Mistris, yet I'le have about with him, albeit he be a Senatours son in law, with a mischief to his heart, when such Gentlemen of estates as I, am shak'd off.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p:
And for me, since Cassio has got my Mistris: let him keep her: I must look out for some other great match in time; for they say, Manduco, that now since the ●uk's restor'd, they who were active in the late rebellion, must be forfeit of their estates: and
what will become of my Patrimony then: for you know my father has been a great man all this while, (I fear he never be so again) now, you know, if I loss my Estate, how shall I have a wife then? what think you, Pantaloni?

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Nay, I can think on nothing now, but how to thrust at Leonardo.

sp.speaker: Bec.
sp.p: So, I will draw too, if you come to that with it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And for me— I love no dimication— but when I am provoked, I will assist you— Et sic arma amens capio, nec sat rationis in armis.

div.stage: Man. puts the hilts of his sword betwixt his feet, and tuggs at it violently.
Enter Cassio, Leonardo, with Chrys. Mar.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Madam, my resolution was alwayes unfeigned to serve you: your coy refusal diminished nothing of my affection, but did rather incite me the more to love you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I did alwayes esteem my self honoured in your love, Sir, though the capricious humors of my self-seeking friends did countermand my desires,

div.stage: Bec. runs away, Man. and Pant. retire to a corner of the Theatre.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nay then, unspotted beauty, answer those gracious obligations your self: it passes the activity of my invention. I have been alwayes your devout admirer; but now I am so much bound to love you, that although my affection should super-erogat, yet I can plead no merits.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: Sir, your merits have made conquest of my affections—

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: Prethee, Leonardo, would'st see good sport—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, you must stay, I will not fight alone.

div.stage: Pantaloni and Man. justles, Pant. wrestles loose, Man. solus to Cass. and Leon.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Fy, not before women, Sir, that were unhandsom—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Keep off, boni viri; for, if you approach, you shall find the vinegar of my wrath. I have chastised many such in my time, I'l make you know what it is rem habere cum Professore, to bell the cat with one to whom you owe respect.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Thou slovenly, greazy Pedant, glass-gazing, superficial affected peece of ignorance, get you gone, speak no more ill of Gentlemen; or if you do, you may come to carry your joynts in a box yet—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Never again, Sir— lets fall his sword.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: If you do— Man. Ita me Deus amet, never, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: We'll put you to the stripado, if you don't behave your self more civily.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Never again, as I am erudit●— So help me, God— never.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Poor fellow, he must have his humour.

sp.speaker: Chrys.
sp.p: If he could hold his peace sometimes, he is a good honest fellow; but he can speak good of no man, but those of his own profession.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: We have punished him sufficiently, let's think no more upon him.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.p: Nor upon our quondam Rivals either. Come, we'll continue our progress to Court.

div.head: Scaena Quinta.
div.stage: A joyfull noise within, Trumpets, Ketle-drums, Ho-boyes, with all sort of musick.
Enter the Duke, Marciano, with others of the Nobility, Courtiers and Attendants, at his entry.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Now, Cleon, divine Cleon mounts His Throne,
Room— room— room— room for Him alone.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Heavens yet are just: they now have paid us home
Our former losses with large interest—
— A good while lost is never known to many,
An ill while feel'd is scarcely known to any:
For men, like butter-flyes, rush on the candle
Of war at all occasions, untill some
Are burn'd to ashes: others hurt their wings;
Then they recoil amaz'd, and not while then,
They blame the projects of their troubled brain.
— Now (gods assume our thanks) we, who before,
Were toss'd in waves of war, are so no more—
— Florence, take heed, jest not with supreme Powers,
'Tis hard to thrive, when heavens do countermand
Thy foul designs:— But wisely learn to know
Thy former errors, and commit no moe.

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: — A Prince's word is good divinity—

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: — While Subjects oaths are down-right perjury,
And serve for nothing but to feed Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: How! Marciano, you seem discontent,
What sullen cloud amid'st this calm of joyes
O'●casts you noble soul?— Marc. Not I, dear Prince,
I am not discontent.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Come, Marciano, you shall feast your senses
On what we know your soul entirely loves.
— Now let us in, 'tis time we were at counsell.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Dull man, do'st not see in his countenance
As one might freely say he did enhaunce,
Cannot thy tongue pay tribute to his praise?
And every one their voices raise.
Why silent then, when after all our tears,
Clouds which did shroud the light, our Sun appears?
Dissolving all our jealousies and fears.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: ALl now rejoyce, but I: my former griefs
Still dwell with me, untill the noble, constant,
Generous Marciano doth appear—
— Goodness! 'tis he— O!
how my heart begins,
sp.stage: Enter Marciano discoursing quietly with a Courtier. Exit Court.
sp.l: Even as a murder'd carcasse, to distill
Gross drams of blood at sight o'th murderer.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: — Cold vertue guard me— if I dream not— 'tis she.
— Mercifull heavens, can Marciano see
His very soul? yet not in extasie.
— O! Arabella, fairest, ever worthy,
I offer thus my heart— thus— thus— and thus—
O! art assist me— suddain joy had never
Suddain expression—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sure, my Lord, you cannot
Be more surprised then I am; pray imagine
A heart abstract from cares, and hois'd in high
Raptures of joy; even such you may define,
Mine-thine— thine-mine— the gods could ne'r have been
More gracious then now—
embraces. Then, thus, my Lord, pray let me evidence
The temper of my heart, since you went hence.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: O! thou, the loadstone of my else-wandring fancy,
That keeps my soul still fix'd— what can I render
Conform to thy fair merits—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Love, my Lord,
— Love, love— I say, I cannot ask for more.
Next, if you will oblige me, prethee honour
Our friend Falasse, one deserves your favour.
— He entertain'd me kindly in your absence,
During your long exile.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Heavens thank him for it,
I shall esteem him highly, and recommend
Him to the Duke— But now, my heart's in flames—
aside.— Never was man more happy in his choyce
Then I in mine— Such Mistrisses are rare—
You were my fellow-sufferer; sprightly Nymph,
If love connive, would you not willingly
Be sharer with me in my prosperity?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Those, who know all things, know my great ambition.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: No more— no more— we wrong our joyes to stay
On such discourse— 'tis time we supplicate
The gentle Hymen, he shall us unite,
That Florence may behold our joyes compleat.

div.head: Scaena Vltima.
div.stage: Enter two of the guard with Partuysans,

sp.speaker: 1. Part.
sp.p: COme, Come, all things will now resume their ancient splendour.

sp.speaker: 2. Part.
sp.p: Yes, yes, now we begin, like Marriners after a tempest, to suck our bottles at ease again.

sp.speaker: 1. Part.
sp.p: O brave dayes! who would have dream'd on this suddain revolution some years since.

sp.speaker: 2. Part.
sp.p: No more of that discourse, look to the Court-gates, for there shall be such a crowd of Gallants with their Ladies, Apprentises with their Wenches, Citizens with their Wives, and all the confused rabble, by and by, that we shall have a great labour on't to keep the half on'em out.

sp.speaker: 1. Part.
sp.p: Right, for the Lord Marciano is to be marryed to night, and we shall have a Masque, I warrand you.

sp.speaker: 2. Part.
sp.p: I beleeve we shall have a merry night on't.

sp.speaker: 1. Part.
sp.p: You are welcome, my masters, walk towards the further corner, pray you, there you shall have best room.

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.p: The Duke will be here by and by. 1. Part. We expect so Sir,

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Come then, wee'l aside, Cassio.

div.stage: A flourish within, Musick, &c. Enter moe Partuysans.

sp.speaker: Part.
sp.l: Clear the way, the Dukes a coming.

div.stage: Enter Cleon, leading Arabella by the hand▪ Courtiers, Attendants, &c.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: — Remember no more, fair Lady,
O● by gone miseries—

div.stage: Cass. Leon. Chrys. Mar. kiss the Dukes hand, &c.
Enter Marciano with Strenuo, presents him to the Duke, &c.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: May it please your Highness—
This was my friend, my very trusty friend
In all my exigencies, very kind
To both me and the Lady Arabella.
Here only, I present him to your Highness—

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Whatever favours were bestow'd on you,
We do account them done to our selves—
— You are his friend, so, Signior, you are ours.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.l: May all the blessings of the heavens combine
To raise your highness to a pitch divine—

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: My Lord Marciano, we have alwayes had
A narrow eye over all your proceedings,
Wee've found you loyall, without spot or blemish,
Valiant, at all adventures, ever faithfull,
And therefore after mature deliberation,
We here entrust the Government of Siena,
Your native country, to your managing—
gives him a Patent. Here's our Commission— take it, and remember
Our honour, and the humours of Siena.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Great Prince, whose daring eye strikes traytors dumb,
Revives all loyal souls: disperses all
Rebellions foggy mists: you have this day
Conferr'd such honour on your highness servant,
As were I a base Infidel, yow'd perswade
My heart to faith, my tongue to oratory—
— Thus— thus, dear Prince, I tender solemnly,
All homage to your highness, while I dye.

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: Arise, enjoy those honours, and approve
Your self a pattern of both fear and love.

div.stage: Cleon takes him by the hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: — Serenissime, Augustissime— dux

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: — Remove, remove that fellow.

sp.speaker: Part.
sp.p: — Come— come Sirrah, you think you are in your school. Man. Dux—

div.stage: Enter Man. Bec-Pant. Strenuo presents them severally to kisse the Dukes hand. Man. harangues.

sp.speaker: Part.
sp.l: Come you villain.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Princeps— Tus— Tus— caniae.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: What an impudent rogue is this?

sp.speaker: Cleon.
sp.l: — As for this Lady, whom thy gentler fates
Have still reserved for your chast embraces,
We still will honour her, as having seen
Evident signs of her affection,
And loyalty to us—

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: And still shall be,
Dear Prince, so much as in a Woman lyes,
I'le offer prayers and tears, and sacrifice,
The first fruits of my wishes; I'le implore
Such blessings, as the gods have heap'd in store,
May rain upon your royal highness head,
That in your eyes heavens favours may be read—

sp.speaker: 1. Court.
sp.l: May forrein Princes his great power envy—

sp.speaker: 2. Court.
sp.l: May he his treacherous enemies plots defye—

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: May he restore our former happiness—

sp.speaker: Cass.
sp.l: And Medicis great princely house encrease—

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: While all his faithfull Subjects long to see
The royal hopes of his posterity—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: — Long live our Prince, and may he still appear,
The brightest Star in all our Hemisphaere.
A joyfull noise within, &c.
